title: [User Story] User retrieves forgotten password
body:
[User Story] | Forgotten password retrieval/reset
----------|----------
Epic Title | #65 
T-shirt size: S(mall), M(edium), L(arge) | 
User Story | "As a user of NEXT, I cannot remember what password I used and I need a reminder/reset so that I can get back into the system and do useful work."
Acceptance Criteria/Tests | A valid user of NEXT can request a pw hint or reset without being logged into the system.  Once the request has been initiated, they should be able to recall/reset the PW within moments and get back to work.
Details/Questions | The acceptance criteria and description are intentionally vague to leave open possible options for implementation. 

- should this trigger an email with a link to a page where I can reset my password?
- should we have them store a hint when they create the pw and this process just email them their hint?
- should this trigger a pw reset and we send them a temporary pw that must be reset on first use?

Related to #546 -- it looks like we have a link in the UI for 'forgot password' that prompts for your email address but doesn't seem to do anything.

title: Add expiration date to role membership
body:
Sets expiration to the one year anniversary of the role creation
date for imported roles, or 6 months after membership grant for
grants that occur on NEXT.

Passes through user and role creation dates from LDAP.
Adds create dates on users, roles, role memberships and proposals, and close date on proposals.

Resolves issue #861 (execution of the expiration will need a new issue) and backend support for #786 

Message payload metadata (inputs, outputs, signer) consolidated into a message payload object, and added now (current timestamp) so the current time can be accessed within the transaction processor.

Expiration periods are temporary defaults until configurations are added.

title: S9 [Task] Divorce user_ids from public keys
body:
Task | Divorce user_ids from public keys
----------|----------
Task Title | Divorce user_ids from public keys
User Story | In support of #898 - The legacy implementation required user_id be equal to the user's public key. This will not remain true with respect to users imported from identity providers.
Description | Eliminates the linkage between user_id and public key. Adds the Sawtooth message to add a public key to the blockchain and assign it to a user.
Business Need (the why): | The first time a user logs into the application, a new Key is generated for that user. The public key of that key must be stored on-chain such that message signatures can be authenticated against registered keys and against business rules on authorized users and permissions required to execute actions on the system. 
Applications or Systems impacted |
Dependencies |

title: Wraps outbound delta sync in check for terminatedError
body:
Wraps the outbound delta sync in a try/catch for session termination:
https://github.com/hyperledger/sawtooth-next-directory/pull/900

And am going to request that, if we open this defect again, we are specific about which sync fails (initial, delta)(inbound, outbound) and include steps to reproduce what we are experiencing. I would rather avoid wrapping in generic Exception because doing so risks any unrelated Exception causing an endless loop of non-deterministic effect.

Resolves #810

title: S9 [User Story] Adding inbound users to the authorization with the same password
body:
[User Story] Adding inbound user to the authorization table all with the same password
----------|----------
User Story Title | Adding inbound user to the authorization table all with the same password
T-shirt size: S(mall), M(edium), L(arge) | s
User Story | As a person giving a demo, I want to be able to login as any user stored in azure or ldap with the same password so Demo goes smooth
Description | Currently every user that is ingested is unable to login, because it is not added to the authorization table.  We need to be able to have this logged in to be able to login to set hierarchies that have already been set up.  This also creates a public key onto the ingestion payload and on the authorization entry.
 Acceptance Criteria/Tests | Can log in as a user and create a role and not break the UI.  Also look at hierarchy org chart to ensure that it is working.

title: BUG -- initial landing page chatbot UI not in sync
body:
Currently when I log into NEXT, I am dropped into a role page and chatbot is suggesting that perhaps I would benefit from getting permissions for a role.  The role on the page and the role suggested by Chatbot are not the same...  

Also, when I ask for this role, Chatbot demands that I draft a message for "none" -- I'm assuming this should be the owner of the role.  Are we grabbing a real field from the backend that isn't populated yet -- or is this UI hardcoded this way?

title: Get the friendly URL working again for demo
body:
User Story | We shouldn't have to remember an arcane IP address, get the friendly URL again
----------|----------

title: Changes create to new on transaction library
body:
Changes create to new on transaction library

Create took two optional params, object_id and related_id
and would do a create + get if they were passed. However,
having changed create to accept named key arguments, we
now need those key values for regular transaction parameters
in order to make proposal actions generic in the way the API
calls them. Thus, the new method only creates an object and
returns the status, and get should be called separately.

Changing the method name from "create" to "new" to support 
an object named create on the library, as we have user.create 
and user.import messages.

PR addresses issue #678, a dependency of #379

title: Narrow try/catch on delta_sync validation error
body:
I made these changes during yesterday's merge of ldap connection resilience, ldap paging, logger migration.

A decision was made to move ValidationExceptions beyond the validator function into getters for users/groups. Because of this, determining where a ValidationError comes from is less obvious/complicated, and the delta_outbound_sync worked around this by putting everything into a try/catch block.

This PR narrows the focus of the try/catch for ValidationException to the specific user/group functions that eventually throw it. There is no new functionality here, and this work was done while troubleshooting yesterday's pile of issues.

title: [Bug] Semantic /dist package is not being built in the client container
body:
**Problem:** The client container startup fails with error: 

`rbac-client | Failed to compile.
rbac-client | 
rbac-client | ./src/semantic/semantic.css (./node_modules/css-loader??ref--6-oneOf-3-1!./node_modules/postcss-loader/src??postcss!./src/semantic/semantic.css)
rbac-client | Module not found: Can't resolve './dist/themes/default/assets/fonts/brand-icons.eot' in '/client/src/semantic'
`

**Workaround:** From the client module, in a terminal, run command: 'yarn build:semantic'. This will compile the /dist directory in your project and make it available to the client container via volumne mount on startup.

**Fix:** Either commit the dist package to git or incorporate the compilation step into the client setup steps

title: Re-Authorization: Create new messages for reauthorizations
body:
Create new messages for re-authorizations.

A "re-auth" request for role membership will need permission from both the role owner and the requestor's organizational manager.  This type of request shouldn't be acted upon until both permissions have been given.

If either approver rejects the proposal, the user's access to the role shall remain until it expires normally.  (the rejection is on the approval to reauth, not on their current access)

If both approver's Approve of the proposal, the new approval date in the user's access will be set to current date.  

Question: given that last line above, we will lose some history regarding how long a user has had this access -- we won't know he has been reauthed several times  -- do we care?  It should be written in the ledger anyway and can be reviewed there.

User Story Title | Setup SSL/TLS connections on Demo environment
----------|----------
User Story | Setup SSL/TLS connections on Demo environment
T-Shirt Size | S
Story Points | 2
User Story | "As a Sawtooth NEXT consuming enterprise, I want my personally identifiable information to be protected in transit"
Description | Setting up SSL/TLS connections (use https versus http) on our demo environment will ensure data is being encrypted as it goes through the NEXT demo. One method we could go with is to implement an optional NGINX container, pass in an SSL certificate that listens on port 443 and redirects traffic to port 4201.
Business Need (the why): | SSL/TLS connections are needed to encrypt traffic within NEXT and prevent malicious actors from sniffing the traffic, helping us satisfy privacy laws.
Acceptance Criteria/Tests | The UI and REST API endpoints should be available at https://next.corporate.t-mobile.com

Details | Explore the HL projects for self-signed certs in pre-prod environments, https://hyperledger.github.io/composer/v0.19/integrating/securing-the-rest-server

title: Implement approval request escalation trigger
body:
Add the capability to escalate an approval request to NEXT. This feature will assist in demoing functionality, and may serve a practical purpose to the UI:
  - Create an endpoint that, when called via POST, escalates an approval request up a level in the org hierarchy.
    - Lookup the approval request
    - If found and still open, find the designated approver
    - Lookup the person (boss) in the org hierarchy the designated approver reports to
    - Assign the approval request to the boss.

title: Validate/verify 'on_behalf_of' business logic
body:
When an approval comes in with 'on_behalf_of' set (see #852):
  - Fetch the user associated with the userId specified by 'on_behalf_of'
  - Verify the user is below the approver in the org chart/hierarchy/reporting chain
     - Reject approvals not meeting these criteria
     - Confirm approvals meeting these criteria

title: [User Story] Unique Version stamp on each build,
body:
User Story  | Visible version stamp in NEXT UI.
---------|----------
T-shirt size:  | S
User Story | We should have a way to uniquely identify each build of our application.  This lets us communicate to our users in a definitive manner regarding functionality and bugs.


**Description**  : This can be implemented a number of ways...  an About box in the UI somewhere is one example.  Each automated build should be tagged with a unique number that follows a predictable pattern.  ~~"Major.minor.date.time" is one such pattern but if our build system automatically generates one too then we could use that.~~ As per Dustin's suggestion we'll use the short hash of the most recent git commit (you can get this running `git describe --tags` in the repo). Useful information on setting up git tagging (which we haven't done yet) can be found [here](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/5694389/get-the-short-git-version-hash), [here](https://git-scm.com/book/en/v2/Git-Basics-Tagging), and [here](https://coderwall.com/p/hwmmsq/sync-application-version-with-git-tag-automatically).


**Acceptance Criteria** 
1) Each merge to master should trigger a new version stamp, 
2) Version is visible to user in the UI, 
3) build log should include version info so we can recreate the state of the product to any point in the past.


Tasks:

- [x] Save version number from the VERSION file in .env file. Pass the verison number to the front end client service.

- [ ] Display version number on UI

User Story | Unique Identifiers will change when a migration occurs from AD (LDAP) -> AAD (Azure). We need to have consistent object_id's before and after migration.
Description | A possible solution to that is to have a lookup table that maps UUIDs to object_ids in a many-to-one manner (multiple UUIDs may map to the same object_id). Thus, both LDAP UUIDs and Azure UUIDs can be supported and map to the correct object.

title: Implement server-side pagination for api calls yielding high results
body:
In cases where a view in NEXT comprises data that can potentially become very large (eg browsing proposals, users, roles, packs. https://www.dropbox.com/s/ccdzd1dy7bfo3xc/B1.png) implement server-side pagination to cut down the payload/time over the wire. 

- [ ] Determine where the data is being queried from (formerly pseudo-relational tables, more recently 'state')
- [ ] Add support to the endpoint for limiting the range of results ( query params )
- [ ] Write the query that filters on the given range params

Acceptance criteria: 
- Demo in the UI. If the feature is not available in the UI, demo using a rest client.
- Given a GET request to a lookup endpoint having a specified page length, the api should yield a list of results that is less than or equal to the specified page length. If results = 12, page size is 10, then page 1 should have 10 results.
- The api should be able to show traversal across several pages. If results = 50, page size is 8, then the call for page 2 should return (considering base index of 1) results in 9-16.
- Traversals should stop at either end of the list without breaking. If results = 15, page size is 10, then page 2 should have 5 results and traverse no further.
- Paging should be stateless. Any lookup of any range of results should be available in the api at all times. Any and all state management must happen in the UI.

title: Implement Custom Image Support
body:
In the NEXT UI are user image stubs. In order to make these actual images that users can manage, there needs to be a service and repository (ie lightweight CMS) on the backend that allows the UI to implement this feature.
- Create the service for user image management
  - Create an endpoint for multipart file upload POSTs by userId
  - Create an endpoint for retrieving the latest user image using a GET
  - Determine the most effective means of storing/retrieving the user images (file system, database, and trade-offs)

- Feature: Users can upload their own profile images
- Feature: Pack editors can upload an image/avatar for their specific Pack

title: Email - Webhook for 'Approve/Reject' flow from email
body:
User Story | Email - Webhook for 'Approve/Reject' flow from email
----------|----------
Epic Title | Alerting
T-shirt size:  | 
User Story | "As an Approver in NEXT, I want to be able to respond approval requests directly in the email message I receive to approve or reject a request without opening the NEXT client.  This allows me to respond to approvals in a timely manner."

**Description** 
- Any email notification requiring action on the recipient's part should include the appropriate response buttons.
- pressing the buttons in the mail registers the response with NexT application the same as it would if the response had been made via the UI
- The types of emails that will use this feature include (but not limited to)
     - Singleton approval requests
     - delegation requests

Question: 
- what do we do for summarized access request emails?  When reauth season kicks off, I would rather get one mail with 15 requests than get 15 emails with one request each.  Will the email have the capability of selecting a subset of the requests and approving?  Maybe the right thing for such emails is to have APPROVE ALL, REJECT ALL buttons and direct the recipient to the client UI if they wish to make subset selections.
- Are the buttons disabled somehow once I have responded the first time?  Should a response somehow move the mail to the deleted items folder (like meeting requests in Outlook?)

**Acceptance Criteria/Tests**
- For the given email requests above, user shall be able to respond by selecting the buttons in the UI.
- reopening the mail and responding in a different way is the same as story #1229 -- it records a second response that supersedes the first one.
- demonstrate that this functionality works with top 5 most popular corporate email clients (as well as on devices)

title: S8 [User Story] Bot socket reconnection and manual override
body:
User Story | Bot socket reconnection and manual override
----------|----------
Epic Title | (Epic NAME)
User Story Title | Bot socket reconnection and manual override
T-shirt size: S(mall), M(edium), L(arge) | 
Story Points - Fibonacci (1,2,3,5,8,13) | 3
User Story | As a user, I don't want to be in scenario wherein I can't request access given the bot server is unavailable.
Description | Take a look at WebSocket API on MDN. WebSocket.open / .close, onerror, onclose. Take a look at https://github.com/lukeed/sockette/blob/master/src/index.js for code to use in client. When or if the websocket connection is broken, the saga channel event handler should attempt to reconnect to the server websocket for n number of times using a timeout. for example, wait 1 second, then try again for 5 times. if it doesn't resolve, then show an error message. Second part: Chat should display button that calls 'manualRequest' function in chat.js in the event that a response hasnt come from the server after 5 seconds.

UX/UI Details and/or mockups | if UI change, a mockup or description of what to change, attach image/file
Applications or Systems impacted | upstream/downstream applications/systems
Dependencies | non story dependencies
Assumptions | if any
Performance Considerations | Will the work performed as part of this story impact system performance. If there is potential for a performance hit, where would you expect it to manifest in the system.
Security Considerations | E.g., does this story involve working with Personal Identifying Information (PII)? Note any such security sensitive aspects.
QA Considerations | what might be hard to test or test setup criteria
Acrhitectural/System or Component Impacts | if we're adding something new or significantly changing architecture flag for architect review
Reverse Engineering Required | to document areas not known well by dev team
Questions/Clarifications | Create new issue (add label: question) in this repo and link to this issue

title: [User Story] Migrate to T-Mobile Azure Eventhub instances
body:
User Story | Create new Azure Eventhubs
----------|----------
Task Title | Recover Azure Eventhub instances
Epic | #49 
T-shirt size default is S(mall) | S
Description | rbac-providers-azure was failing to connect to azure. We found that the Eventhub namespace that we use in azure was down and causing the issue. 

The 2 Eventhub instances in the namespace were deleted, so we need to create 2 new Eventhub instances within the old namespace. They were deleted because the account was a demo account with a trial period that expired.

The first Eventhub, an audit log, should take all change logs from our AAD instance and feed them into our StreamAnalytics instance which filters out the events that we can't process. A second outbound log EventHub should be made that takes in logs from StreamAnalytics and makes them available to our rbac-providers-azure service.
Business Need (the why): | Currently blocking in/outbound AAD sync development.
Applications or Systems impacted | rbac-providers-azure

The new EventHubs will be registered with an official, financed TMO account. As such, once setup, they are not expected to disappear again.

title: Modified LDAP delta sync process all data types

group objects. With this change, there is only one inbound delta sync
thread that will look for both LDAP objects that have been updated.

Each object that gets updated in LDAP will be saved in the sync_tracker
table as its own record.

title: Investigate replacing RethinkDb with a Graph database

title: Base Docker images on the dependencies they will use
body:
Some work has been done to optimize caching of the docker base images and layers. However, it has led to a number of images based on sawtooth-validator. This base image includes the components sawtooth uses to implement consensus, and these components are not leveraged by a few images that extend it (ad/aad syncs, and *possibly* server).

For the non-implementing images, explore a better fit for base image - something that provides only what the image will actually build upon and nothing more. Replace the sawtooth-validator bases with this (python? alpine?)

title: Add a CONTRIBUTORS.md that sends Hyperledger Access Ticket Emails on Change
body:
A recommendation from @ryjones :

Add a CONTRIBUTORS.md file to the project that, when new members are added, sends requests for their repo access to the Hyperledger Help Desk. 

Apparently, this is how they do it in Hyperledger Fabric. I am not sure how, but am assuming in our case that it would involve adding a script to Travis that inspects the file on merge.

Having it in place would save time spend manually sending emails for every new contributor.

title: Chatbot request access
body:
### Auth:
  - No longer possible to retrieve JWT from JS
  - Websocket handshake secured
  - Webhook endpoint secured using JWT sent in Rasa slot
  - **Note:** CSRF not addressed in this PR
  
### CORS:
  - Added CORS sugar used for per-resource policy enforcement
  - API CORS policy disallows `*`
  - **Note:** `CLIENT_HOST` passed to CORS is for connection from outside Docker

### Webhook:
  - Prevent requests from blocking event loop
  - Add ability for webhook to request role membership

### Diagram:
![](https://www.dropbox.com/s/ekm6u4pc6rl3uhi/NEXT%20Flowcharts-Chatbot%20Security.png?raw=1)

Signed-off-by: PGobz <p.gobin@gmail.com>

title: Rename requirement.local.txt
body:
requirement.local.txt (Should be requirements.local.txt) appears to be enabling some new contributor to run something. However, the dependencies described within are in the first 2 lines of requirements.txt. 

We had some discussion about this file, and its existence has yet to prove any value at this time, yet its deletion is disputed. It appears as though we need to save it because some new contributor hypothetically could come along in the future and start using it.

In cases such as where nobody currently uses the file.. where the file does not add value to the project.. the file is effectively cruft that should be deleted. Created this ticket since there is disagreement about this concept.

title: Create RethinkDb tables before starting Docker containers that use them
body:
The RethinkDb tables are being created within ledger_sync for no justifiable reason. When other containers start up before ledger_sync, workarounds need to be put in the code to ensure the apps wait for the tables to appear.

Instead, the database setup should happen before the dependent containers are brought up at all. This ensures now special treatment needs to be written into connectors that works around an existing design flaw.

S7 [User Story] Next-Sawtooth Intake: Validate NEXT payload
body: Validate the record pulled in from 'queue_inbound'

title: S7 [User Story] Next-Sawtooth Intake: Listen and process new records
body:
- [x] Set up a worker to ingest change entries from inbound_queue. 
- [ ] Validate the records as User objects
- [ ] Transform the records if needed to be valid NEXT user/group objects.
- [ ] Save the records to Sawtooth (update or create as needed).

title: S7 [User Story] Next-Sawtooth Intake: Fetch preexisting records
body:
This story follows #667

Connect to RethinkDb's 'queue_inbound' table and query for all records. Similar to the provider lookups except without the filter (ie importing records for all providers)

title: S7 [User Story] Next-Sawtooth Intake: Create module/deployable
body:
Create the module (Dockerfile, fixturing, ...) necessary to run this service

Treat the Next-Sawtooth intake as a provider, follow the pattern set by the AAD and LDAP providers and place the module in `rbac/providers/next/`

Module will contain:
- Module directory
- Dockerfile
- Starter script in `/bin/` (use LDAP/AAD provider starter scripts as a guide)

title: Onboard chatbot engine
body:
## Reading:
[Understand the Rasa Stack](https://rasa.com/docs/get_started_step1/)

> The Rasa Stack is a framework to build contextual AI assistants and chatbots. It consists of two open source libraries (Rasa NLU and Rasa Core).

[NLU](https://rasa.com/docs/nlu/)

> Rasa NLU is an open-source natural language processing tool for intent classification and entity extraction in chatbots. For example, taking a sentence like

[Architecture](https://rasa.com/docs/core/architecture/)

## In this PR:
- Add Docker service based on Rasa Core from `rasa/rasa_core:0.12.2`
- Add WebSocket route to server for handling chatbot requests
- Add NLU language processor
- Add script to train Core and NLU
- Add initial training data

## Gist:
- `bin/train` trains Core and NLU from documents in `/chatbot`
- Core server waits for incoming requests on port 5005
- JS client sends message payload to `/api/chatbot` over `ws://` as serialized JSON
- REST server POSTs to Core server, providing it conversational context via user ID
- Core server replies with chatbot response `->` REST server responds `->` Client displays view

## Notes:
- Client changes not included

## Todo:
- Conversations exist in memory. Create adapter for Rethink.
- REST auth middleware doesn't yet use token from socket handshake

Signed-off-by: PGobz <p.gobin@gmail.com>

title: 593 process existing outbound ldap records on startup
body:
Adds the capability to process preexisting ldap records in the outbound queue table. Since the changefeed only picks up on events that happen after its instantiation, any previous records are ignored. This change ensures the previous records are processed first. 

There are some files in this PR that are still in flux due to a refactor that happened mid-feature-development. I have another branch in progress for incorporating the existing ldap inbound sync functionality.

title: Fixed AD/AAD initial syncs checking uninitialized table
body:
There was a bug in which both initial syncs were checking sync_tracker
table before it was being initialized. Now, the check will wait until
the table has been initialized.

Also there was a bug with ExpectedError class where it was not
printing properly. That bug was also fixed in this PR.

title: [Spike] Investigate adding a Message Broker to NEXT in place of RethinkDb queue tables
body:
We used queue tables in RethinkDb to move quickly during the hackathon with Microsoft. These tables are being used to essentially carry out Pub/Sub in NEXT. This is the behavior of a message broker. 

Sawtooth uses zeroMq for its messaging. A popular message broker for OSS projects is RabbitMq. Using a message broker simplifies such matters as bulk/time-offset replay, failover into backout queues, etc. 

There is a library for rethinkDb called repubsub (https://github.com/rethinkdb/example-pubsub/tree/master/python) although it is a bit dated (apparently it once integrated well with RabbitMq).

title: S6+/S7+ [Story] Relocate LDAP delta sync from outbound coroutine to a new inbound coroutine
body:
I inadvertently removed the inbound delta sync from the outbound queue processor's coroutine.

It should not be there. Coroutines run their operations synchronously. And inbound sync in the outbound coroutine will block it. 

Create a separate coroutine dedicated to processing inbound messages and add the function there.

the ability to abstract out common functionality into
base classes.

title: Scale up/out RethinkDb
body:
Since day 1, we have been seeing warnings coming out of RethinkDb about it using swap space:

rbac-rethink | warn: Some RethinkDB data on this server has been placed into swap memory. This may impact performance.

We haven't put much load on it yet. 

Research and implement the best means of scaling it to handle the expected data load (more memory? More nodes?)

Related to story #729 perhaps?

title: Re-Addressing Scheme
body:
Migrates to a new blockchain addressing scheme

Address is a 35-byte (70 character) lowercase hexadecimal string
        in the following format:
            3-bytes (6 characters): Transaction Family Namespace
            2-bytes (4 characters): Reserved (zero bytes)
            2-bytes (4 characters): Hex representation of the object type (enum value)
            12-bytes (24 characters): Hash of the object id
            2-bytes (4 characters): Hex representation of the related object type (enum value)
            1-byte (2 characters): Hex representation of the relationship type (enum value)
            12-bytes (24 characters): Hash of the related object id or zero bytes if None
            1-byte (2 characters): Reserved (zero bytes)

title: Data Storage and Schema
body:
Epic | Data Storage and Schema
----------|----------
Epic Title | Data Storage
T-shirt size default is L(arge) | L
Description | Determine how and where data will be stored, how it will be addressed, how it will be modeled, how it will be queried, how it will be replicated, how it will be persisted, how it will be backed up.
Details | Sawtooth provides a replicated and immutable key-value data store with transactional history where key is a 35-byte address and value is an opaque string. This is effectively a NOSQL data store, the addressing scheme is up to the application to invent. RethinkDB provides a document database with a streaming changelog API.

title: Process outbound queue for LDAP user/group entries
body:
If the outbound queue entry has a data type of group or user and has a provider ID containing a AD domain controller, then the entry will be processed and AD will reflect the new changes.

First commit resolves issue #505 
Second commit resolves issue #506

title: [User Story] Implement APScheduler-based daemon/processor
body:
We had a vote on how to move forward with our processor daemons and agreed to migrate over to ApScheduler. Currently, the only scheduled coroutine solution we have in place is Tornado. ApScheduler was chosen for its focus on job scheduling (tornado also contains webserver capabilities). Priorities have shifted, so this task is backlogged for now.

Implement a POC listener based on APScheduler (replace tornado?)

title: Adopt APScheduler for all things scheduled and polling
body: Per the 11/6 Technical feature discussion: Adopt [APScheduler](https://apscheduler.readthedocs.io/en/latest/) for all cases where a task is scheduled that polls AD/AAD/RethinkDb for changes. Get a generic pattern in place that can be used whenever a daemon is needed.

title: Update lint shell script such that it reports when a target directory is absent
body:
In bin/run_lint.sh are a list of directories PyLint runs against when 'bin/build -l' is executed. 

The first list is for cli arg filtering and the second is for default execution.

(Try to) Move the paths into a list to be referenced by both. 

The args already has a check for the provided option. However, in the second block: When a directory in the list is missing (ie a code refactoring/rename happens), this script fails with non-obvious errors. 

Check for the existence of the directories before linting them. Fail with an obvious error when any are missing.

title: S5+ [User Story] Restore images corrupted by gitattributes change
body: The NEXT directory logos were corrupted in a change intended to enable the project to run in WIN environments. The gitattributes file has since been updated to support both WIN file endings as well as images, but the logos are corrupted. Fix them.

title: Move black to local requirements
body:
Move black to local requirements
Black is not compatible with Python 3.5

Local requirements will capture additional requirements for local development environment that do not need to be installed by CI/CD services (Travis, ReadTheDocs, etc). Local dev environment may use Python 3.7 (with caution, code must still be compatible with Python 3.5.2).

title: S5+ Replace all usages of print() in python files with LOGGER.[level]()
body:
All messages meant to report errors, assist in debugging, track progress... should be logged rather than printed to standard out. 

Replace all usages of print() in python files with log statements. 

Pay attention to variables passed into print statements as invalid substitution causes errors and concatenation fails in linting.

title: Merging Requirements files
body: Signed-off-by: Nadia Bahrami <nadia.bahrami@dev9.com>

title: [Story] Consolidate the getenv() function and rename to something that describes the added behavior
body:
Duplicated throughout the codebase is the following function:

def getenv(name, default):
    value = os.getenv(name)
    if value is None or value is "":
        return default
    return value

The implementation adds support for a None result returned from os.getenv(). 

Having the function duplicated across the codebase creates the risk that any changes made to any copy will result in inconsistent behavior, especially if/when the function is directly imported. 

Consolidate this function into one location so changes made will benefit all users of it. 
Rename the function to disambiguate it from os.getenv. There are a few cases where it has been renamed to get_env_with_fallback()

title: Request for a documentation on this project
body:
Hello Team,

Sorry for posting it as an issue as i didn't find any other way to communicate with the team.

Could you please provide all the BDD stories or any requirement document for this project?
I am a new babe in the block-chain area and i feel this will be a good exploratory project for me.
Any help on this would be highly appreciated.

title: LDAP Inbound Queue and AD Dump
body:
The PR commit resolves #272, #277, #279, #321, #328, #346 

The first commit consists of the AD user dump through a initial sync over LDAP. The second commit consists of the delta sync that pulls any changes from AD since the last sync was performed. The initial sync currently runs every time docker containers start (provided that the AD credentials are set in environment variables). The delta sync runs every 3600 seconds (one hour) by default and can be set in the environment variable.

title: Add Swagger UI to the project
body:
The project has an openapi document that has been manually maintained over time.

It will need Swagger pages that deploy along with the rest-api per future integration plans within the TMO services ecosystem ( Integration with Clearwater repo )

Compare a few options and implement the most well-maintained, user-friendly solution.

A few to options to start looking into:
https://pypi.org/project/sanic-swagger/
https://pypi.org/project/sanic-attrs/

title: Uniform Dockerfiles
body:
This promotes volume mounts to the default configuration
and removes the seperate "dev" mode.

This makes all docker files use a base set of common
dependencies to maximize docker image caching.

Renamed tmobile-rbac to hyperledger-rbac as the working
directory name. Run bin/clean to remove pycache directories
that may otherwise cause an error.

bin/clean will also suggest pruning all existing docker
images. That is optional but recommended.

bin/start, bin/start -d and docker-compose up are equivalent.
still use the -b flag as --build or -p flag for persistent
data on bin/start.

Terming into the containers shows the old tmobile working path.
This may be cached somewhere else, cd .. && cd hyperledger-rbac

Issue #291 #353 #354

title: [HOTFIX] (Re)build by default in start script
body:

body:
[User Story] | RBAC Outbound Groups Membership Sync
----------|----------
Epic Title | #333 
User Story Title | RBAC Outbound Groups Membership Sync
T-shirt size: S(mall), M(edium), L(arge) | M
Story Points - Fibonacci (1,2,3,5,8,13) | 2
User Story | Modifying group membership in RBAC should modify the membership in the identity providers, via an outbound queue. This will populate that outbound queue.
Business Need (the why): | This is one of the basic functions of NexT -- write back to identity provider(s)
Acceptance Criteria/Tests |  A change to a role, membership, etc should result in changes being written back to the identity provider(s) -- view a setting in AD directly, make a change in Next and then look again in AD -- be sure it is reflected there.  ?  Is there a more robust way to prove this works?
Questions/Clarifications | This story is simply to get correctly formatted items into the outbound queue?  Then there is another story (or existing functionality) for processing them?

title: [User Story] RBAC Inbound User Delta Sync
body:
[User Story] | RBAC Inbound User Delta Sync
----------|----------
Epic Title | #333 
User Story Title | RBAC Inbound User Delta Sync
T-shirt size:  | L
Story Points - Fibonacci (1,2,3,5,8,13) | 5
User Story | Modifying a user in linked identity provider should modify the user in RBAC, via an inbound queue. This will monitor the inbound queue and modify the user in RBAC.

**Acceptance Criteria**
1) be sure we cover all the CRUD scenarios on the AD side.  For all objects that we are tracking here.  Users and Roles get created, updated and deleted all the time...  inbound delta sync needs to handle them.

- [x] Create a new user in NEXT that was created in AD.
- [x] Create a new role in NEXT that was created in AD.
- [x] Update any parameter (from /rbac/providers/common/provider_transforms.py) of a current user that was edited in AD.
- [x] Update any parameter (from rbac/providers/common/provider_transforms.py) of a current role in NEXT that was edited in AD. 
- [ ] Delete a user in NEXT that was removed from AD.
- Check to see if role gets updated after a user is deleted and is a member of the role
- [ ] Delete a role in NEXT that was removed from AD.
- Check to see users gets updated after a role is deleted and the users are members of the role

title: [User Story] RBAC Outbound User Create Sync
body:
[User Story] | RBAC Outbound User Create Sync
----------|----------
Epic Title | #333 
User Story Title | RBAC Outbound User Create Sync
T-shirt size:  | M
Story Points - Fibonacci (1,2,3,5,8,13) | 2
User Story | Creating a user in RBAC should create a user in outbound identity sync queue such that it can be picked up and created in the identity provider.
Acceptance Criteria/Tests |   Demonstrate that creating a new user acct in Next *should* cause that user to also be created in the identity providers it is linked to...  It should replicate the user in ALL systems that we sync to.
Question | is this correct?  Does Next have enough info to create a new user in the upstream systems -- stuff like what org they belong to, badge number, start date, contact info, etc, etc...  But we kinda *need* to have the ability to create a user in those systems if we expect to use Next to assign roles.  @chrisspanton need some input here

title: S4/5+ [User Story] AAD Outbound Sync - D sync
body:
Committed, but uncaptured - S4 carryover

User Story Title |  [User Story] AAD Outbound Sync
T-shirt size: S(mall), M(edium), L(arge) | M
Story Points - Fibonacci (1,2,3,5,8,13) | 5
User Story | "As an administrator of the NEXT platform implementing NEXT into my organization, I want to have the ability to export my organization's NEXT data (users and groups) into AAD. I need the data to be on the platform to perform RBAC duties"
Description | A NEXT outbound queue is needed to allow organizations to integrate their users and groups created on the NEXT platform with their AAD installation. The sync will be a delta sync and will be used to grab any differences in NEXT from the last outbound sync queued up in a RethinkDB table called ad_inbound_queue to be exported to AAD. Differences consist of changes to Users or Groups made within NEXT.
Business Need (the why): | To allow for organizations to easily adopt the NEXT platform for their RBAC management, the platform should include an option to export users and groups to AAD. This outbound queue will store all the records from NEXT before it gets saved in AAD.
Details | AAD Delta Outbound Sync, New Outbound Queue table RethinkDB
Acceptance Criteria/Tests | 1) Have a new RethinkDB table called ad_outbound_queue 2) Delta sync function to grab differences in Next data from last sync from ad_outbound_queue, write them to AAD, and add them to ad_outbound_queue.completed. May still need UAT or SIT / integration testing with other stories.
Failure | Not all data records from NEXT were imported to ad_outbound_queue
Definition of Done | Sync reflects the latest version of NEXT data from the ad_outbound_queue table and adds that data to AAD.                                                                                                  
UX/UI Details and/or mockups | if UI change, a mockup or description of what to change, attach image/file
Applications or Systems impacted | Access to AAD test environment
Dependencies | no story dependencies
Assumptions | N/A
Performance Considerations | Syncs should be as efficient as possible as AAD could contain a large set of data.
QA Considerations | Large NEXT data exports
Acrhitectural/System or Component Impacts | if we're adding something new or significantly changing architecture flag for architect review

*AAD = Azure Active Directory

title: S5+ [User Story] AAD Delta Sync
body:
[User Story] [Epic] | Multi-party approval, Approval configuration
----------|----------
User Story Title | 
T-shirt size: S(mall), M(edium), L(arge) | M
Story Points - Fibonacci (1,2,3,5,8,13) | 5
User Story | "As an administrator of the NEXT platform implementing NEXT into my organization, I want to have the ability to import my organization's Active Directory data (users and groups) into NEXT. I need the data to be on the platform to perform RBAC duties"
Description | An Active Directory data inbound queue is needed to allow organizations to integrate their existing users and groups into the NEXT platform. Two syncs will be created. The first sync is the initial sync that pulls all the data from an organization's AAD and queues it up to be saved on the Sawtooth network. The second sync will be the delta sync. The delta sync will be used to grab any differences from the last inbound sync (could either be a initial sync or a delta sync). Both syncs will be send data to a new RethinkDB table called ad_inbound_queue.
Business Need (the why): | To allow for organizations to easily adopt the NEXT platform for their RBAC management, the platform should include an option to import users from AAD. This inbound queue will store all the records from AAD before it gets saved on the Sawtooth blockchain.
Details | AAD Initial Sync, AAD Delta Sync, New Inbound Queue table RethinkDB
Additional User Story | S4+ [User Story] LDAP AD Inbound Queue #321
Acceptance Criteria/Tests | 1) Have a new RethinkDB table called ad_inbound_queue 2) Initial sync function to grab all AAD data and add those records to ad_inbound_queue 3) Delta sync function to grab differences in AAD data from last sync and add those records to ad_inbound_queue.
Failure | Not all data records from AAD were imported to ad_inbound_queue
Definition of Done | Both syncs reflects the latest version of AD data and adds that data to the ad_inbound_queue table.                                                                                          
UX/UI Details and/or mockups | if UI change, a mockup or description of what to change, attach image/file
Applications or Systems impacted | Access to AAD test environment
Dependencies | no story dependencies
Assumptions | N/A
Performance Considerations | Syncs should be as efficient as possible as AAD could contain a large set of data.
QA Considerations | Large AAD data imports
Acrhitectural/System or Component Impacts | if we're adding something new or significantly changing architecture flag for architect review

*AAD = Azure Active Directory

title: S6 [User Story] Integrate the record retrieved from queue_outbound insertion event to Active Directory
body:
Title | Send the record retrieved from outbound_queue to Active Directory
----------|----------
Epic | #50
T-shirt size default is S(mall) | S
Story Points - Fibonacci (1,2,3,5) | 2
User Story | As an administrator of NEXT, I want to modify Active Directory based on incoming changes in the queue_outbound, to allow both AD and NEXT to sync with each other. 
Description | Send the message retrieved in #313 to Active Directory. Once Sawtooth data has been imported into outbound_queue, go through the outbound_queue to modify AD according to match data in Sawtooth blockchain. 
Business Need (the why): | Changes in NEXT should be reflected in Active Directory
Acceptance Criteria/Tests | Any changes to user or group objects in NEXT will be changed within AD. If new users or groups need to be created in AD, they must have the required attribute fields first before they can be created. Any new users or group that will be created, must be unique. 

- [x] Build out initial feature 
- [ ] Merge refactored WIP from AD/AAD common functionality

Business Need (the why) | AD users should be able to log in to NEXT because the NEXT platform should be the main tool used for the management (granting access, updating, deleted, etc.) of AD roles.

title: travis changes to add pylint
body: Signed-off-by: Nadia Bahrami <nadia.bahrami@dev9.com>

title: Add linting
body: Linting made available through npm run lint.

title: Deprecate pycrypto in favor of cryptography package
body:
Getting rid of pycrypto which is no longer maintained for
the cryptography package for AES encryption.

Took the opportunity to deprecate config.py given its AES
key is no longer compatible. New AES key must be 32 bytes
(64 hex characters). Configuration should be passed in via
environment variables (docker-compose or .env) or command
line arguments.

Existing users are not compatible with this update, start
with fresh data. Delete persistent data volumes.

RESET_NEXT_STORAGE

Signed-off-by: Adam Gering <adam.gering@dev9.com>

title: Format and setup.cfg modifications
body:
Adding subfolder to linter and formatter

This PR takes care of:
#218 and #197 
lint runners will now produce the same errors
modules ignores have been minimized
formatting changes have been made

title: Imports the python Sawtooth Rest Client from Sawtooth Core
body:
Imports the python Sawtooth Rest Client from Sawtooth Core 
 
Having this library available in the RBAC source makes this library and
its functionality more transparent and available to developers.
 
Additionally, it allows suppression of verbose debug/info logging it
otherwise generates when used in development & tests.

title: Aligns Python paths in the IDE
body:
There is no change to functionality with this.  There is a lot of movement within folders to centralize all python files under one RBAC.  
Folders that have been moved under rbac folder are:
addressing
ledger_sync
processor
server
transaction_creation

modifications to bin folders have been made to change the pathing to run the build scripts
modifications have been made to DockerFiles to be able to build correctly with new pathing

Pathing is now explicit to avoid IDE issues of recognizing imports 

Testing to make sure this succeeds still included:
./bin/build -d
./bin/build -l
./bin/build -t
./bin/build -p
./bin/build -i

while ./bin/build -d was up shelling in and running pytest tests/

and running scripts:
./bin/run_python_formatter
./bin/run_lint
python ./bin/populate_test_data.py

If pulling down to verify that this works you may need to follow the steps in the README under Cleaning the Docker Image Cache

title: S3 Implemented multi-node configuration
body:
Resolves #159

After running docker-compose -f docker-multi-node.yaml up command,
four nodes will be created with each node hosting an instance of
Sawtooth Next Directory. Each node will have access to the blockchain
and will utilize a simulated version of PoET. The Next Directory UI
will be available at:
http://10.5.0.70:4200
http://10.5.0.71:4200
http://10.5.0.72:4200
http://10.5.0.73:4200

Note: Because user accounts authorization is currently being stored in the rethinkdb auth table and not being stored on the blockchain, when a user is created on a specific node, that user cannot sign in on a different node. All other data is shared among the four nodes.

Signed-off-by: Michael Nguyen <michael.nguyen79@t-mobile.com>

title: Activate linting policy for too-many-args
body:
User Story | Activate linting rule for too-many-args
----------|----------
T-shirt size | M 
Story Points - Fibonacci (1,2,3,5) | 5
Description | Too many arguments is a code smell for a more simple design. The linter rule for this has been disabled while linting is being incorporated into build automation (get linter running first, fix violations incrementally). This rule was identifying violations before disablement, so we know there are at least a few cases of it in the python code. Enable the rule locally, fix the violations, and push the new policy. 
Business Need (the why): | Fewer args in functions implies the code is easier to comprehend and less likely to include side effects.

title: Updated deploy.sh to reset data
body:
Deploy.sh now resets the data on the remote server back to genesis.
To have the script reset the data, include the phrase
"RESET_NEXT_STORAGE" (without the quotes) in the commit message.
If the phrase is not in the commit message, the script will shutdown
and restart the containers maintaining the persistent data.

Resolves #177

title: Consolidates tests and using pytest marking
body:
Consolidates test in the /tests directory.
Sets up tests to be run via ```pytest```
Adds pytest marking annotations (e.g. ```@pytest.mark.unit```)
so you can pick which tests to run.
```pytest -m "unit"``` for unit tests
```pytest -m "integration"``` for integration tests
Tests may be run and re-run interactively via shell.
```docker exec -it rbac-shell bash```
```pytest```
Or one-off via a clean docker image:
```bin/build -t```

Resolves #147, addresses #106 and #143

title: Add requirements.txt to manage python container dependencies
body: Fix Issue #171 - Added requirements.txt to each python container directory to manage dependencies and edited Dockerfiles to use requirements.txt where appropriate.

title: Implemented deployment script for master branch
body:
Implemented deployment script of master branch to a remote server.
Once a PR gets merged into master and all tests in travis passes,
travis will SSH into the remote server and push the new changes
from the master branch into the remote server. The deploy.sh script
run docker-compose down to shutdown the running containers on the
remote server. After a succesful shutdown, the script will spin up
the NEXT containers in persistent data mode.

Relates to Issue #103 

Signed-off-by: Michael Nguyen <michael.nguyen79@t-mobile.com>

title: [Task] Add script to update requirements.txt and update README.md
body:
Task | Add script to update requirements.txt, update README.md and CONTRIBUTING.md
----------|----------
Task Title | requirements.txt update script and README.md
T-shirt size default is S(mall) | S
Story Points - Fibonacci (1,2,3,5) | 3
Description | PR #166 adds a requirements.txt file with all of the python project dependencies for new contributors to install. `pipreqs` is already being used to initialize requirements.txt, and we already have a recursive script to format/lint all python scripts in this project, so we could use it to maintain requirements.txt as well. We'll also need to update README.md with instructions for running the script.
Business Need (the why): | Adding this to a recursive script like `bin/run_lint` would mean developers won't have to update requirements.txt, reducing the chance of missing dependencies.
Dependencies | PR #166, Issue #171

title: [Task] Use requirements.txt in python Dockerfiles
body:
Task | Use requirements.txt in python Dockerfiles
----------|----------
Task Title | e.g. Use requirements.txt in python Dockerfiles
T-shirt size default is S(mall) | S
Story Points - Fibonacci (1,2,3,5) | 2
Description | Python Dockerfiles currently install dependencies through pip manually with `RUN`, meaning developers must edit the Dockerfiles to add/remove dependencies. We should use `pipreqs` to generate a requirements.txt file in each container directory and use `RUN pip3 install -r requirements.txt` after mounting the volumes in the container with `COPY`. Then developers only need to edit requirements.txt to add or remove python dependencies.  
Business Need (the why): | Contributors shouldn't have to touch the Dockerfiles unless they're actually changing the container itself.

title: Write Ledger Sync Unit Tests
body:
Task | Write Ledger Sync Unit Tests
----------|----------
Task Title | Write Ledger Sync Unit Tests
User Story | #106 
T-shirt size default is S(mall) | M
Story Points - Fibonacci (1,2,3,5) | 3

title: Adding requirements.txt to manage global developer python dependencies
body:
Added a requirements.txt for developers to install python dependencies (linter will return import errors if all dependencies are not installed locally). I need create tasks to:
- add instructions to readme.md on using requirements.txt
- add requirements.txt for each container directory
- add a script to bin for updating all requirements.txt files

Run `pip3 install -r requirements.txt` in the root project directory to install development dependencies for the project.

title: Issue #150
body:
Resolves Issue #150 

- Moved Pylint config settings from .pylintrc to setup.cfg (we already define pep8 configs in setup.cfg).
- Pylint is no longer checking formatting. Pylint will be used to detect code errors and warnings only.
- Black will be used to handle formatting/code-style.
- bin/run_lint now runs black on a file before linting to auto-correct formatting issues.
- Users must have Black and Pylint installed locally to run run_lint
- Related to PR #166

title: Fix: Cannot perform read: primary replica for shard (LedgerSync/RethinkDB)
S2+ Increases unit test coverage of addresser
body:
Task | Increases unit test coverage of addresser
----------|----------
Task Title | Increases unit test coverage of addresser
T-shirt size default is S(mall) | S
Story Points - Fibonacci (1,2,3,5) | 1

---
This increases test coverage of the addresser, and breaks the tests out into pieces for maintainability and self-documentation.

Run using ```pytest```

It makes one small code change to validate the entire address string via regular expression instead of just checking the prefix of the string.

It does not attempt comprehensive test coverage of the addresser, but enough to facilitate future refactoring of the addressing code and addressing scheme.

Resolves Issue #141

title: S2 Add base UI scaffolding
body:
## UI scaffolding

UI scaffolding based on CRA from Facebook. Redux/Sagas with React
Router, reduxsauce (sugar/utility), seamless-immutable (immutable
data structures), and Semantic UI.

.travis.yml has been split into two stages; one for the backend and
one for the frontend. The frontend build is on LTS, which as of this
commit is v8.12.

Root project Dockerfile has not been modified. If you would like to
test the new client in the context of Docker, simply switch ports
`4200 -> 3000` and directory `./ui -> ./client`.

Signed-off-by: PGobz <p.gobin@gmail.com>

![Train](https://i.gifer.com/2swA.gif)

[Task] | Add base UI scaffolding
----------|----------
Task Title | Add base UI scaffolding

title: S3 [Task] Update Copyright header in project file headers
body:
[Tech Debt] | Update the copyright in file headers
----------|----------
Epic Title | Conformance with Hyperledger standards
T-shirt size: S(mall), M(edium), L(arge) | S
Story Points - Fibonacci (1,2,3,5,8,13) | 2
User Story | "As an attorney, I want to see clear attribution in every file in the project's codebase"
Details | Per the Apache 2 license recommendations and expectations of the Hyperledger project: Every file in the NEXT Directory codebase should have a header including default Apache 2 boilerplate, current year, and copyright owner (in this case: Hyperledger Authors). Currently, some files specify T-Mobile, Intel, etc. as the owners, the dates are off, and some files don't have the header whatsoever. The task here is to refactor the headers in the codebase to display uniformly/consistently, the copyright that follows

    Copyright 2018 Contributors to Hyperledger Sawtooth
    
    Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License");
    you may not use this file except in compliance with the License.
    You may obtain a copy of the License at
    
        http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0
    
    Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software
    distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS,
    WITHOUT WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied.
    See the License for the specific language governing permissions and
    limitations under the License.
    -----------------------------------------------------------------------------

title: S2 + [Task] [Bug] Cannot perform read: primary replica for shard (LedgerSync/RethinkDB)
body:
Bug | Cannot perform read: primary replica for shard
----------|----------
Task Title | Cannot perform read: primary replica for shard
User Story | #109
Epic |  #109
T-shirt size default is S(mall) | S
Story Points - Fibonacci (1,2,3,5) | 2
Description | Cannot perform read: primary replica for shard ["", +inf) not available in:
occurs often when the system is started with persistent data
This appears to be a recurring and known issue with RethinkDB.
Restarting the ledger_sync container will eventually both show the problem again but fix it.
It's likely needed to handle database connection  retries (+ delays on retrying) in a more robust manner.
Applications or Systems impacted | ledger_sync
Dependencies | ledger_sync, rethink

Reproduce: 
```bin/start -p```
Add some initial data

```bin/stop```
```bin/start -p``` 

Error will show: (reproduces most of the time)
```rbac-ledger-sync | Cannot perform read: primary replica for shard ["", +inf) not available in:```
```rbac-ledger-sync | Unsubscribing from client events```

```rbac-ledger-sync``` will still be running but will not be subscribed to events.

Workaround: in another tab while running: ```docker restart rbac-ledger-sync```

Restart will show the error again. Not sure if those are stale logs or not (investigating). However, further down will read:

```rbac-ledger-sync | Successfully subscribed to state delta events```

title: [Design] Hierarchical Approval
body:
Epic | Hierarchical Approval
----------|----------
Epic Title | Hierarchical Approval
T-shirt size default is L(arge) | L
Description | In the event a designated approver is unavailable to approve identify access request, the system shall automatically re-direct the request to the next level up in that approver's organization.
Business Need (the why) | Technology allowing approvals to **automatically advance up** the organizational chart. This proactively moves requests from being stale in the system and not being addressed timely. Benefits the approver from having a backlog of requests.
Stakeholders | requester (manager, next level up), requestee
Details | Hierarchical definition is defined in #32 and will be administered in the approval engine, Epic #64 
User Scenarios | #32, #81 
Acceptance Criteria/Tests | _The list of tests or criteria to be used to validate the story has been completed. May still need UAT or SIT / integration testing with other stories._
Failure | _if any, fold in negative tests_
Definition of Done | After a pre-defined time has been reached for an approval, system shall automatically escalate approval request to the approvers next level up.                                                                                                 
UX/UI Details and/or mockups | _if UI change, a mockup or description of what to change, attach image/file_
Applications or Systems impacted | _upstream/downstream applications/systems_
Dependencies | 
Assumptions | 1) Requestor ia authorized to approve for requestee. 2) Requestor and Requestee are valid entities 3) Requestor's next level up approver is a valid entity
Performance Considerations | _Will the work performed as part of this story impact system performance. If there is potential for a performance hit, where would you expect it to manifest in the system._
Security Considerations | _E.g., does this story involve working with Personal Identifying Information (PII)? Note any such security sensitive aspects._
QA Considerations | _what might be hard to test or test setup criteria_
Acrhitectural/System or Component Impacts | _if we're adding something new or significantly changing architecture flag for architect review_
Reverse Engineering Required | _to document areas not known well by dev team_
Questions/Clarifications | _Create new issue (add label: question) in this repo and link to this issue_

title: Multi-Party Approval
body:
Epic | Multi-Party Approval
----------|----------
Epic Title | Multi-Party Approval
T-shirt size default is L(arge) | L
Description | Allow for system to automatically triage approvals needing more than one person's approval prior to provisioning permissions to applications/systems for a specific person as per request.

Multi-Party Approval
The first supported scenario for multi-party approval will be for re-authorizations.
  

That means, someone is a member of a role, but their membership in that role must be re-confirmed or it will expire.
Re-Authorization is required by at least one role owner, and by the manager of the member.
Thus, from a User Interface standpoint, the first requirement is to visually distinguish Access Requests from Re-Authorization Requests.
We will add a type on the proposal, so you can distinguish them.
For example, presently we have type = ADD_ROLE_MEMBER
We will add REAUTH_ROLE_MEMBER
A question for @ChrisSpanton, if someone REJECTS a REAUTH request, does the member lose access to that role immediately or upon expiration. I presume the former.
The other element of Multi-Party Re-Authorization scenario, is that the user's manager will see the request in addition to the role owners. For this, the User Interface doesn't need to do anything; that assignment happens on the back-end.
So really, that is all there is to our first supported Multi-Party approval scenario. @pgobin
  

To demo this feature, we can configure reauthorization to be required every 6 months, and that re-authorization requests occur 6 months prior to expiration. In reality, the values will be 6 months and perhaps 1 month respectively.

A question regarding this feature, I presume the user should need to enter a reason why they still need access to the role prior to the Re-Auth Request being visible to the approvers? CC @ChrisSpanton 

From a security standpoint, it could be valuable to allow any role owner to require any (or all) existing members to re-authorize. (A manual re-authorization trigger)
We could also configure a SECURITY_LEVEL configuration on a role, and have SECURITY_LEVEL = 1 (default) require 1 role owner, but SECURITY_LEVEL= 2 require 1 role owner + the manager. Thus would be equivalent to the Multi-Party requirements of Re-Auth, but requires no UI change at all.

title: S2+ [User Story] [Bug] Unable to approve open proposals
body:
After PR #53 was merged, open proposals are now unable to be approved. User kelly_ on Hyperledger Chat reported this issue and here was the error they received when they approved a new user to join a group:

```
rbac-tp_1 | [2018-09-10 19:10:27.113 DEBUG core] received message of type: TP_PROCESS_REQUEST
rbac-tp_1 | [2018-09-10 19:10:27.117 WARNING core] Invalid Transaction The proposal 8cbf5aaf-f7d7-4a2c-8010-5a15a1e71b26 does not exist or is not open
rbac-server_1 | Bad Request: The proposal 8cbf5aaf-f7d7-4a2c-8010-5a15a1e71b26 does not exist or is not open
```

The Invalid Transaction error should not have been thrown as the user created proposal `8cbf5aaf-f7d7-4a2c-8010-5a15a1e71b26`.  If a user is authorized to approve a proposal, the expected result would not  throw any error message. 

Bug|[Bug] Unable to approve open proposals
----------|----------
T-shirt size: S(mall), M(edium), L(arge) | M
Story Points - Fibonacci (1,2,3,5,8,13) | 5

title: S2+ [Task] [Enhancement] Option for persistent data
body:
There should be an option to run the application with data persistence.

Task | Persistent Data
----------|----------
Task Title | Persistent Data Docker Config
User Story | #74 Non-Blockchain Data Storage
Epic | #74 Non-Blockchain Data Storage
T-shirt size  | S
Story Points - Fibonacci (1,2,3,5) | 1
Description | Setup docker options to store data persistently
Business Need (the why): | Allows for restarts and rebuilds while leaving data intact, to mimic production environment and to facilitate testing.
Applications or Systems impacted | docker compose builds

Presently there does not appear an option to do so.

`docker-compose up`

Create users, etc...

`docker-compose down`
`docker-compose up`

All data is gone.

title: S1 [Bug] Stopping and restarting Application results in unexpected application behavior
body:
Stopping and restarting the application via `docker` results in unexpected application behavior.

`docker-compose up`

Create some users.

`docker-compose stop`
`docker-compose up`

Result: ledger-sync_1 failures.
Can log in but can't sign up or create new users.

Works only by taking the app down and then up.

`docker-compose down`
`docker-compose up`

However, that will remove all data and start from scratch.

title: Issue #26 fix - task owner/admin permissions
body:
This PR fixes #26 and fixes #63. Now, owners and admins for a particular task has the ability to add and remove additional task owners and task admins. Also, open proposals can now be approved by authorized parties.

Here is my integration test results for the changes made in this PR. 
[PR_60_integration_tests_results.txt](https://github.com/hyperledger/sawtooth-next-directory/files/2377083/PR_60_integration_tests_results.txt)

Once this PR has been merged I will create a new because as I attempt to add a task admin that I just removed from a task, I am getting the following error message: 

`{
     "message": "Bad Request: Txn signer 03e25d64ca81318344513d887c4244d53963f9538d8ba12b8d1055410ae0519066 is not the user or the user's manager ['0210adc09ac5ea4eeb3f02188240a21fd7f8886e08cdfc1ef94f90cbfe21086ed0', ''] nor the task owner / admin",
      "code": 400
}`

Further investigation will be needed as I was initially able to add user `0210adc09ac5ea4eeb3f02188240a21fd7f8886e08cdfc1ef94f90cbfe21086ed0` to the task as a task admin. After removing user `0210adc09ac5ea4eeb3f02188240a21fd7f8886e08cdfc1ef94f90cbfe21086ed0` and attempting to add them again to the task, I run into this 400 error code.

title: S2 [User Story][UX Design] End State View (UX and Visual Language)- Finalize the design concept and visuals
S2+ [User Story] [Enhancement] | Enable the project to deploy standalone out-of-the-box
body:
[Enhancement] | Enable the project to deploy standalone out-of-the-box
----------|----------
Epic Title | Developer-friendly codebase
T-shirt size: S(mall), M(edium), L(arge) | S
Story Points - Fibonacci (1,2,3,5,8,13) | 2
User Story | "As a developer, I want to easily deploy the application and quickly diagnose errors in deployment"
Details | The current sources provide a config.sample.py that is to be copied and renamed to config.py before the application can deploy to localhost. There are a number of issues with the current setup. When config.py is missing: * The app builds and deploys without errors  * Errors in the server are hidden within its container * Errors in the UI come out as CORS violations * An unmanaged default config is easily lost in forking
Acceptance Criteria/Tests | The code can be checked out and the application started locally without side effects or errors

title: S2+ Provides a default configuration for localhost out-of-the-box
body:
[Task] | Provides a default config for localhost out-of-the-box
----------|----------
Task Title | Provides a default config for localhost out-of-the-box
T-shirt size | M
Story Points - Fibonacci (1,2,3,5,8,13) | 5

The current sources provide a config.sample.py that is to be
copied and renamed to config.py before the application can deploy
to localhost. There are a number of issues with the current setup.
When config.py is missing:

  *  The app builds and deploys without errors
  *  Errors in the server are hidden within its container
  *  Errors in the UI come out as CORS violations
  *  An unmanaged default config is easily lost in forking

This change designates config.py as config-localhost.py and
references it by default in main.py in a constant,
CONFIG_OVERRIDE_FILE. This allows the application to deploy
out-of-the-box.

Resolves #57 
See also: #40

Signed-off-by: keithbloomfield <kthblmfld@gmail.com>

body:

----------|----------

User Story | As a NEXT approver, I want to designate a permanent proxy who can review and approve/disapprove application/system access on my behalf.

**Acceptance Criteria/Tests** 
- Same basic functionality as Temp delegation but this has no end date. 
- Can be terminated if the orginater sets an end date.

title: Short-Term Delegation
body:
Epic | Short-term delegation
----------|----------
Epic Title | Short-term delegation
Tasks | Define Short-term delegation #68 
User Story | As an approver in NEXT, I want to be able to designate a proxy who can review and approve/reject proposals for a defined period. 
Description | e.g. if manager will be going on vacation, allow them ability to assign for a limited time a specific person who can approve/disapprove.  Ensure assignee is allowed per policy.
Business Need (the why): | allows for no delays in access request in the event a NEXT user is out of office, on medical leave, vacation, etc.
Details | 
Additional User Story |
Acceptance Criteria/Tests | (see bulleted list below)   
Failure | designated proxy doesn't receive requests
Questions/Clarifications | 

- demo the UI for assigning a delegate. 
- Any pending requests already in the queue when delegation starts/stops shall be transferred to/from delegate. 
- Delegate request includes a message to delegate. 
- Delegate request shall trigger an email to recipient.  
- Approval/rejection of said request shall trigger an email notification to the requestor.
- during the duration of the delegation, any escalations that happen should still go to orginal owner manager (correct @chrisspanton )
- any place the role/pack owner name is referenced (ChatBot) during the delegation period, the delegate's name will be used.
- The granularity of the time interval shall be 'day' so transfers of proposals should begin/end at midnight (of which timezone?  Do we know the timezones of the two parties?)
- delegations shall be nestable or overlap-able -- multiple levels of delegation allowed.  We kinda need this if we are going to allow permanent delegations.
- originator of delegation can end it prematurely by resetting the end date -- but doesn't kick in until midnight
- The originator's people manager can modify the delegation (If I go on paternity leave and delegate to a peer, and then extend my leave by a week, I can call my boss and have them extend delegation)  This will trigger another accept email to the delegate.
- Anyone in the org is allowed to be delegated to and deal with approvals -- not limited to originators current org, his directs, etc...  
- if the delegate leaves the company all of their delegations shall revert back to originator (?  Does an email get triggered to someone here?)
- if the originator leaves the company during the time period should all ownership immediately revert to the manager?

title: Batch Approval
body:
Epic | Batch Approval
----------|----------
Epic Title | Batch Approval
User Story | As a NEXT user, I want to approve or disapprove multiple application/system requests in one session so I don't have to retrieve each request one at a time.
Description | Ability to approve requests in a batch
Business Need (the why): | Approval engine feature. Built-in intelligence in the engine.
Additional User Story | all approval types in scope: expiration, re-authorization of access, new access
Acceptance Criteria/Tests | A NEXT admin can approve a bulk number of requests from the UI  There should be UI where role/pack owner can select which of the pending requests to process and then which result (so pick 3 of the 5 pending and approve, then pick the remaining 2 and reject).  Should also have the ability to simply "select all."
Definition of Done | Moments after an admin selects a batch of users and clicks "Approve", the approvals will be evident in Sawtooth and queries against RethinkDb                                                                                   
Questions/Clarifications | 12/7 - Keith: Regarding the "engine" described above: I believe we have settled on (at least initially) multi-approvals being carried out on the UI as a series of individual approvals processed in a loop. That is, the rest api doesn't require an additional endpoint for batch approval (just the existing single approval).

title: [GitHub] What permission sets can we create on the repo?
body:
Looks like Wiki is either public (every Github user) or private (only users with push access).

Looks like Project is ready-only for everyone but users with push access.

Looks like Issues can be created with read-only access, but no assignment can be performed (Assignees, Labels, Projects and Milestones).

Issue Templates can only be created by repo maintainers (in Settings).

Looks like Pull Request can be made with read-only access.

title: Hierarchical Approval V1
body:
Epic | Hierarchical Approval
----------|----------
Functionality | Managers should have the ability to approve what their descendants (including direct reports) would be able to approve. 
Description | 
Stakeholders | requester (manager, next level up), requestee
Related | Approval engine, Epic #64 
Acceptance Criteria/Tests | See bulleted list below
Assumptions | 1) Requestor is authorized to approve for requestee. 2) Requestor and Requestee are valid entities 3) Requestor's next level up approver is a valid entity
Questions |

Acceptance Criteria:
- if manager approves/rejects, we write to the ledger "Manager on behalf of Approver..." so we can clearly see who took the action.
- The original approver should be able to see the manager's approve/reject with manager's name in the recent approvals page.
- the Manager should *also* see the their own name and on behalf of in their recent approval's page.
- if mgr's mgr takes the action we only record & display one level of 'on behalf of' -- (eg. don't show "Jon approved on behalf of Sue on behalf of Kevin on behalf of Amy"  just show "Jon approved on behalf of Amy"   (Or do we need to record this in ledger for audit so we know the state of the org structure at the time?)

@chrisspanton notes on Hierarchical Approval
This one is more difficult from a UI standpoint, because it's not clear where exactly you should see the Pending Requests for your direct reports.
If you can view "yourself" (profile page), then presumably you should be able to see your Direct Reports or even your Org Hierarchy on that page; and be able to click through on any of those people and see "their page".
On their page, recognizing that you are the manager or an ancestor, if you can see that user's view of their Pending Requests, you should be able to approve them on behalf of that user.
That user should be able to see recently approved Requests, and view that it was approved by another person on their behalf.
From a security standpoint, they ought to be able to Revoke that approval, and from an auditing standpoint it would be valuable in my opinion to allow them also to Confirm that approval. CC @chrisspanton

title: S1 Task owners do not have permissions to add/delete task admins
body:
When a task owner attempts to add or delete admins to/from their task, the following error message is outputted:
```
{
   "message": "Bad Request: Txn signer 02a6e8d56db65be8636bf2d23b8741312c0b6385e3354e269b27227b476a735a3a is not the user or the user's manager ['025a476a958b6fb1c762a8a5d674df9130257ab9129ff677e461493b252fbc1ec2', '']",
   "code": 400
}
```

It appears task owners can only add or delete admins only if the task owner is the manager of the targeted user or they are the user themselves. Task owners should have full control of their task and they should have the ability to add/delete admins even if the owner is not the manager of the targeted user or the user being added/deleted. 

### Scenario
The owner of task `6d2956d5-fc09-454f-960e-0578c0ddeff7` would like to add a new task admin. The new admin has the user id `025a476a958b6fb1c762a8a5d674df9130257ab9129ff677e461493b252fbc1ec2`

Here is the CURL request for this operation:
`$ curl -X POST "http://localhost:8000/api/tasks/6d2956d5-fc09-454f-960e-0578c0ddeff7/admins" -H  "accept: application/json" -H  "Authorization: task_owner's_bearer_token" -H  "Content-Type: application/json" -d "{  \"id\": \"025a476a958b6fb1c762a8a5d674df9130257ab9129ff677e461493b252fbc1ec2\"}"
`

### Expected Result
A proposal is created with the type ADD_TASK_ADMINS and the response would contain the proposal ID.
```
{
  "proposal_id": "63467642-6067-4c82-a096-1a1972d776b3"
}
```

### Actual Result
```
{
   "message": "Bad Request: Txn signer 02a6e8d56db65be8636bf2d23b8741312c0b6385e3354e269b27227b476a735a3a is not the user or the user's manager ['025a476a958b6fb1c762a8a5d674df9130257ab9129ff677e461493b252fbc1ec2', '']",
   "code": 400
}
```

After fixing this issue, requests on the 'Requests' and 'Pending Approvals' pages were not displaying the reasoning associated with the request. This PR also fixes this display issue on both pages.
